instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.5V_S0: What is 5V_S0? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S0”.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CHIP>U8080</CHIP>
threads.message: Found <CHIP>U8080</CHIP> to be shorted on this 3437. Changed it, and now on pin 7 (<SIGNAL>P5VS0_FET_RAMP</SIGNAL>) its reading 2.45v... is this typical of this circuit? It looks like there is cap 8081 in line, but this reading seems off. Any insight? (Liquid damaged board) This board isnt powering on, and I am in the process of diagnosis.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CHIP>U8080</CHIP>
threads.message: need the basics. do you have a green/red light on the charger? you should be getting 5v on pin 5 but only if you are getting 5v on pin 1 and 2 of <CHIP>U8080</CHIP>. what pin was shorted to ground on <CHIP>U8080</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CHIP>U8080</CHIP>
threads.message: Enable to <CHIP>U8080</CHIP> is more of interest. First need PPBUS and S5 stuff to be present.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CHIP>U8080</CHIP>
threads.message:
Yes green light on charger, 0 at pin 5
3.3 at the EN pin
I think it was an internal short as the component got hot as hell and burned me.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CHIP>U8080</CHIP>
threads.message: So is 5V on both sides of <CHIP>U8080</CHIP>, if so it is working fine.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CHIP>U8080</CHIP>
threads.message: I have voltage on pins 1, 2, 3 but no voltage at 6 or 7. Same scenario, I change it out, and it gets broiling hot. checked the legs, and no short to ground. I highly doubt its the actual component as I have tried a couple different ones.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CHIP>U8080</CHIP>
threads.message: Something is drawing too much current through <CHIP>U8080</CHIP>. Inject voltage on <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL> and see what heats up.
